breakage, enclosure compromise, and possible injury to the birds.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility did not maintain a program of adequate veterinary care by failing to ensure the availability of appropriate
facilities, and personnel to comply with the Animal Welfare Regulations and Standards.
• Following multiple citations for failing to maintain proper facilities, an email dated May 19, 2025, from the General
Manager to company leadership provided a quote for repairs that would bring the dolphin enclosures back into
compliance. At the time of inspection, the deficiencies had not been corrected and additional requests for approval to
make the necessary repairs remained unanswered. The city of Panama City Beach has also cited the facility for code
violations, including electrical deficiencies and unsafe areas. Failure to maintain appropriate facilities does not support a
program of adequate veterinary care.
• Over the last several months, numerous employees have resigned, including key members of the Animal Care team,
leaving an insufficient number of employees to care for the animals. At the time of inspection, the last on-site member of
the veterinary care team, the sole veterinary technician, informed USDA officials that she had resigned. When asked what
led to this decision, she cited the most recent dolphin death on April 25, 2025, and the lack of an on-site veterinarian or
additional support as the primary factors. Accordingly, the facility does not have the appropriate personnel to ensure a
program of adequate veterinary care.
• The Attending Veterinarian lives in Nevada, leaving only one on-site member of the veterinary staff, a veterinary
technician, to oversee the daily care of all animals on property. Because of the lack of adequate veterinary staff, the
veterinary technician informed USDA officials that she must prioritize the care and treatment of sick animals over routine
care. Routine care is a component of acceptable veterinary standards and failure to meet this component does not ensure
a program of adequate veterinary care.
• Medical Records document that on April 25, 2025, when the veterinary technician was informed of a dolphin found
unresponsive at the bottom of an enclosure, she was forced to call the former Attending Veterinarian for assistance
because the current Attending Veterinarian was at his home in Nevada and there was no other on-site or locally
contracted veterinarian to call. Failure to provide a sufficient number of appropriately trained personnel does not ensure a
program of adequate veterinary care.
Appropriate facilities and a sufficient number of trained employees are necessary for providing the adequate veterinary
care required for the proper husbandry, treatment, and maintenance of the health of the animals.
Each exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the availability of
appropriate facilities and personnel to comply with the provisions of the Animal Welfare Regulations and Standards.

The facility failed to maintain the marine mammal enclosures in good repair to protect the animals from injury. USDA
inspectors identified several areas in disrepair.
• The far west dolphin pool has previously identified cracks in the walls and surrounding concrete which has still not been
addressed and is continuing to break down. These areas have flaking paint, exposed aggregate, and loose stone or
cement pieces which could fall into the water.
• The wooden shade structure over Dolphin Med pool and a portion of Dolphin West has many rusted and pitted joist
hangers. Flakes of rust are observed hanging loosely and can flake off into the water below.
• On the east side of Dolphin East pool, there is a viewing window that is at and below the level of the visitor platform.
There is a leaking crack on the upper left portion of the window frame. There is a small white stalactite, which appears to
be another calthemite formation, at this location and algae can be seen growing on the exterior of the enclosure. The
crack on the outside of the enclosure was wet to touch. There was also visible water on the ledge below the crack.
• The deck is separating from the curb of the pool along the entire north side Dolphin East.
• Cinder block walls behind Dolphin Main, Dolphin East, Dolphin Med Pool, Dolphin West, and Dolphin Far West show
signs of deterioration. The lower course of block has the coating lifting off and the block disintegrating. Material from these
blocks is on the deck and can be blown or washed into the pools housing the dolphins.
Enclosures that are not maintained in good repair can lead to health and well-being hazards to the animals within.
Indoor and outdoor housing facilities for marine mammals must be maintained in good repair.

The facility failed to provide protection from the weather or direct sunlight. Although previously identified, the facility has
not provided shade over the far side of dolphin east pool where dry guest interactions are done, or over the main show
stage where the dolphins station for food during training sessions with the trainers or during public guest interactions after
shows.
Direct sunlight can be uncomfortable and adversely affect the animal’s health.
Natural or artificial shelter shall be provided for all marine mammals kept outdoors to afford them protection from the
weather or from direct sunlight.

The facility does not have a sufficient number of adequately trained personnel and is unable to make the corrections
necessary to comply with the Animal Welfare Act, as indicated by the number of repeat noncompliances identified during
this inspection. The facility's current employees must fulfill collateral duties just to maintain current operations.
Failure to maintain an appropriate number of employees can lead to the inability of the facility to address the corrective
actions necessary to return to compliance.
A sufficient number of adequately trained staff to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry can ensure that optimal
welfare and care can be provided for the animals maintained at this facility. A sufficient number of adequately trained
employees or attendants, responsible to management and working in concert with the attending veterinarian, must be
utilized to maintain the prescribed level of husbandry practices.
A complete routine inspection was conducted starting on 2 June 2025. This inspection report is limited to the Repeat non-
compliances identified during that inspection. An additional inspection report will be delivered with the other issues
identified during this inspection.
This inspection was conducted with facility representatives. The exit briefing was conducted on 3 June 2025, with facility
representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
KRISTIN NAPOLI, SUPERVISORY ANIMAL CARE SPECIALIST n
